slides.title: Native applications
bullets: An application built with the platform specific tools and technologies
Package an application for publishing in a store/market

slides.title: Native iOS by Apple
bullets: Requires membership in the iOS Developer Program $99/year

slides.title: Native Android by Google
bullets: Only requires membership in Market for selling $29/year
Eclipse, Android SDK and the Android plugin for Eclipse (ADT)
Xml-based layouts kind of like html, but totally different elements and styling

slides.title: Different philosophies
bullets: Apps in App Store are audited by Apple before publication
No file system. Limited sharing between apps
Only two devices to target, iPhone(+iPod Touch) and iPad
All apps are accepted into Market and published instantly
Permission system that limits what an app can do (accepted by user when installing)
Has file system. All apps can access SD card. Apps can share both data and functionality.

slides.title: Why native?
bullets: Features not (yet) available on the mobile web

slides.title: There is a middle ground
bullets: Using html, css and javascript but in a web view container, packaged as a native app
Both iOS and Android support displaying a web view/page inside of a native app
+ Feature access can be provided to javascript via native code
- Does nothing for performance and the general "feeling" of a native user interface, or any selling limitations
